Award.AwardTitle: GEM: Understanding the Global Aspects of Plasma Heating in Earth's Magnetosphere
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will investigate how various modes of transport (steady convection and bursty bulk flows/dipolarization fronts) influence the inner magnetosphere and ring current. Observations in the plasma sheet from THEMIS and in the night side radiation belts from the Van Allen Probes will be used to determine how various transport modes affect local properties of the ring current. The evolution of energy spectra, pitch angle distributions and pressure will be examined for the different forms of interaction. One goal will be to determine the relative importance of adiabatic and non-adiabatic acceleration. This study will involve multiple events. In separate but related studies IMAGE HENA observations will be used to determine globally evolving ring current and plasma sheet pressures. This will be done by comparing the spectral and spatial evolution of H and O ions during convection and substorms. Finally a 3D particle trajectory tracing code will be used in the time evolving fields from the Rice Convection Model to evaluate non-adiabatic acceleration mechanisms. HENA observations will be used to determine plasma pressures at synchronous orbit and these will be used as input to the RCM. The resulting pressures from RCM will be compared with the global pressures in the ring current region.

This research will support a post-doctoral researcher and provide early career development for a female scientist.

Performance_Institution.Name: The Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigates the global effects of the so-called plasma pressure encircling the Earth in space and is co-located with the famous radiation belts. The plasma pressure is a core piece of space weather as it drives electrical currents of up to 10 MA in strength, that in turn induce magnetic perturbations on the surface of the Earth. The project has investigated how this plasma pressure comes about and what its global effects are. The project has concluded that the plasma pressure originates predominantly from adiabatic motion of inward moving plasma from about geosynchronous distance (the project did not deal with the physics beyond geosynchronous), and that the plasma pressure is enhanced in large regions extending from one to several earth radii. The project specifically used Van Allen Probe in-situ ion measurements and IMAGE mission ENA images from the HENA camera. Together these two data sets were able to demonstrate how much varying size sudden enhancements of pressure contributed to the total budget of pressure. Simultaneous ground and low-orbit measurements demonstrates that the electrical currents set up by the plasma pressure closes through the ionosphere where it drives ionospheric circulation system from mid- to high latitudes that may be a critical part of how ionospheric plasma is also flowing out from the ionosphere (not part of this project, but a broader science impact). In addition, the outcomes of this project has made important strides towards the combined analysis of the global configuration of the inner magnetosphere during geomagnetic storms using global ENA images and the empirical magnetic field model  TS07d, which has lead to a new effort improving the global now casting of the inner magnetospheric magnetic field configuration and pressure distribution.
